etymology.description: semantic: 糸(糸) (mì, "silk") + phonetic: 屯(屯) (tún, "station") = silk quality -> pure
etymology.interpretation: 纯(純) (chún, "pure") uses silk, symbolizing fine quality, combined with 屯(屯) (tún, "station") to express the idea of pure and unadulterated silk.
etymology.simplification: The character 纯(純) was simplified by removing the middle component from 屯(屯) while retaining the recognizable phonetic and semantic elements.

examples.chinese: 她的心灵纯洁(她的心靈純潔)，她的笑容纯真(她的笑容純真)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de xīnlíng chúnjié, tā de xiàoróng chúnzhēn.
examples.english: Her heart is pure, and her smile is genuine.

examples.chinese: 这首音乐纯粹动人(這首音樂純粹動人)。
examples.english: This piece of music is purely moving.
